name: Single-Handedly
description:
Hello everyone, I've been working on this project for the last week and a half or so, at it's current state it's more of a prototype/proof-of-concept.  The full game I envision would have at least 20-30 more unique items, many more bosses,enemy types, and about 2 more playable characters.  I'd also like to eventually add other environmental tile sets, however art is a large undertaking for me since I'm not too great at pixel art just yet.

Please please forgive the placeholder art, I will be spending more time animating and working on the missing art moving forward.  I just wanted to release this for whatever audience I get, and hopefully you'll all enjoy what I have so far.

I'll appreciate any feedback/input,  but at the end of the day I want to try and make it as close to my vision as possible.  HOWEVER, feel free to let me know what you think please, I won't disregard anyone's input as I feel there will definitely be valuable ones.

The Game:

One night I had this idea that kept me up about a game where the player only gets to move their character around the map while every skill that character uses will be a randomly chosen one from it's load-out that charges up and casts without any input from the player.  This sounded like so much fun so I figured it'd be great if the element of stress from bullet-hell games were involved.  Then I decided to make a few items so the player could scale their characters infinitely, with enough items each run would feel so different from the last that you could always jump in and enjoy yourself with this game. 

Controls:

Arrow Keys/ WASD for movement

Right Arraw/ "D" key for menu selection.

Credits:

My good friend Angell for the awesome hammer character and Nurse art/animations, they look amazing right, as well as input about the direction of the game that no doubt helped me along greatly.

Another buddy of mines named Rahil who helped me greatly with the random level generation.

0x72 - https://itch.io/profile/0x72 - who generously posted their beautiful dungeon tile set for public use, which I fell in love with and decided to keep for the prototype at least.
